div.head: The Authour in his owne defence.
div.l: IF poore man with his paine, May pick vp many a pounde,
If streames with often rayne, May quell the greedie grounde,
If rusticke soyle may yeelde, Both hearbes and flowres faire,
If tylth the hungrie field, May maintaine and repaire:
Then why shoulde Momus howte, Or cauill at my quill,
To see hym now send out, That he hath haachte at will?
Or why shoulde painfull penne, that long hath toyld in hope,
By meanes of spitefull men Be turned all aslope.
As though the Muses all were niggardes now of late,
And would not let the small To enter at their gate:
Or stoupt to none but states, Or lou'd to lodge in Towers,
Disdaining countrie cates Or course contriued bowres.
No no, you neuer knew, That ere they were so strange,
And I dare vouche for true They neuer will so chaunge.
VVhy? did not they attende Diogenes his tubbe?
And meekly to him bend Yea vnder many a shrubbe?
And were they not at hand VVith Arion on the Seas?
VVith Orpheus on the lande Amid the wildernesse?
Let no man nowe then doubt But haply I may show
Such stuffe as late came out, And did in Pernasse grow.
Though that my name be not Among the learned rolde.
Let not that bee a blot Ere that my tale be told.
Yet Zoylus seemes to say, VVhy? what? and whence is he?
A childe but yesterday, And now to scale the skie?
VVhere gathered he his skill? VVhat tutor tolde him in?
The Vniuersities denill That ere he dwelt therein,
And London laughes to thinke She scarce doth knowe hys face,
How commes he then to linke VVith Vranes worthy grace.
My aunsweare shall bee short, My paine this peece hath pend,
God lent it to my lot, And hee shall mee defende.
The Psalmes say sucklinges young His glory shall disclose
VVhich warrants me among My wrangling wrabbish foes.
